title: How many of you use reverb in your music? If so, how and why? If you use it sparingly, why so? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have to say that as someone with a long involvement in music making and recording, I cannot imagine not using reverb! I have recorded lots of tracks for myself and other people, and currently I specialise in doing mixes. In mixing I attempt to get each instrument or voice to sound the best it can, in the context of the whole, but the creation of the whole involves three things: the relative levels (volumes) of each part or voice. This does not have to be static, which is a common mistake among novice mixers, but can rise or fall in the context of the song.The spatial positioning of each part in terms of stereo, that is from left to right. This is something which can be manipulated dynamically, but it is wise not to go overboard with it.the listening space you are creating in the context of the song.The latter is what we use reverb for. It also has an important function in creating the emotional atmosphere of the song. To illustrate, I only need to reference two tracks I’m currently working on. Yesterday I made some progress with a funk instrumental track from a project I’m working on with a friend here in Auckland. It’s mid-tempo, I’ve programmed a tight drum groove, I have a bass guitar part I’m pleased with, but will redo with a few more fills, grace notes and variations, and there are relatively few instrumental parts. There are two reverbs on this - a short, tight one on the drums and percussion parts, and a longe, medium space reverb for keys and guitars. I want the rhythm section to gell together, so the reverb for that is a short plate reverb, with the low end rolled off, so that these separately programmed parts sound more cohesive, without being muddy. The bigger reverb puts a couple of lead parts in a bigger context, along with some delay on a send, and the same reverb is applied to an electric piano part and some ensemble brass. It’s starting to sound good to me. I want the rhythm to have energy, but a lot of big reverb would wash that away. I can afford to get the keys to feel like they’re in a bigger space, without the rhythm stuff sounding separate. It has to sound tight and funky, as if you were hearing it on a club. I never use reverb on bass, at least not for a funky track like this. Today I am beginning work on a track for a client. This is the last track in a progressive rock album I’ve been mixing, which is basically almost a rock opera format, with several lead singers on each track effectively having conversations. It’s a grand, cosmic-scale concept, so the listening space has to be big. I have to choose the right reverb, and will probably try two or three before settling on one to work with. I checked in my Logic Pro X setup, and, including the built-in reverbs, I have 48 reverb plugins! I try to be conservative with the number of reverbs I use on a project, and pretty well always put them on a send, rather than as track inserts, which gives a reverb for each part, as to me that creates a confusing, potentially very messy listening space. I’m very likely to use something like Eventide’s UltraReverb, which has a lot of useful parameters I can tweak, including EQs on input and output, so I’m not putting reverb on deeper sounds and it stays bright. I’m likely to set the Decay Time at 2 seconds, at least, and I will play with the room size. Another trick I might use is to duplicate the reverb on another send, but play with the predelay and use a noise gate on it, to give a very similar sound, but which might help emphasise particular parts. I also have dynamic changes in reverb sends, to highlight vocal phrases in particular. This has been done since the 50s, by hand, but these days I can automate from my DAW.  I mixed a simple acoustic track for a contemporary folk outfit a while back, and they needed to sound as if they were in an interesting intimate space, so I used Waves’ Abbey Road echo chamber reverb recreation. It worked really well for that, but I won’t be using it on the prog rock track. The reverb for that needs to be bigger and grander. If I didn’t have UltraReverb, I might be using Logic’s Space Designer convolution reverb, which is also excellent - I have a lot of good impulse files for that, and it’s also very editable.

I love reverb. I use several kinds, all over the place. I’m sort of an anomaly, though. I’m heavily influenced by post-punk, mid-80’s pop and shoegaze, all of which were pretty reverb-focused (although different kinds of reverb). I’ve got my big slapbacky gated reverb on my snares and toms for that Hugh Padgham vibe. I’ve got lush plates on vocals. I’ve got big lexicon-ish halls on my synth pads. I mean I’m at the point where I’ll use Eventide Blackhole as an insert for some cavernous spatial processing. That’s not normal. But when I do use reverb, I usually slap an EQ (sometimes with fairly extreme settings) in front of it to trim out some low end and sculpt things to sit in the mix - even though most reverbs have their own EQs onboard, with the exception of Fabfilter Pro-R’s I generally find myself needing a bit finer control than the standard shelves/cuts . Sometimes I’ll throw a sidechained compressor on to duck it against another signal and keep it out of the way in a mix. Sometimes I’ll adjust the actual arrangement of the track so various sounds don’t fight with each other when they’ve been processed. I tend to use reverb personally more as an effect than as just a spatial processor. When I’m working with other clients, however, then it’s often a case of trying to sound like a natural space and get it all to sit nicely in the mix. Usually then my rule is “if you can hear how nice the reverb is, there’s too much reverb.”
